title: Water in tub: Modeling Riemann sums

content.question:
t (minutes)
 0
 4

 15
 20

W(t) (degrees Fahrenheit)
 55.0
 57.1
 61.8
 67.9
 71.0

The temperature of water in a tub at time t is modeled by a strictly increasing, twice-differentiable function W, where W(t) is measured in degrees Fahrenheit and t is measured in minutes. At time t = 0, the temperature of the water is 55°F. The water is heated for 30 minutes, beginning at time t = 0. Values of W(t) at selected times t for the first 20 minutes are given in the table above.

(a) Use the data in the table to estimate W'(12). Show the computations that lead to your answer. Using correct units, interpret the meaning of your answer in the context of this problem.

The temperature of water in a tub at time t is modeled by a strictly increasing, twice-differentiable function W, where W(t) is measured in degrees Fahrenheit and t is measured in minutes. At time t = 0, the temperature of the water is 55°F. The water is heated for 30 minutes, beginning at time t = 0. Values of W(t) at selected times t for the first 20 minutes are given in the table above.

(a) Use the data in the table to estimate W'(12). Show the computations that lead to your answer. Using correct units, interpret the meaning of your answer in the context of this problem.

(b) Use the data in the table to evaluate <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mrow> <mn>20</mn></mrow> </msubsup> <msup> <mi>W</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> </mrow> </mstyle><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbiqaaG9gqaaaaa aaaaWdbmaapedapaqaa8qaceWGxbGbauaaaSWdaeaapeGaaGimaaWd aeaapeGaaGOmaiaaicdaa0Gaey4kIipakiaacIcacaWG0bGaaiykai aadsgacaWG0baaaa@40E8@ </annotation> </semantics> </math>. Using correct units, interpret the meaning of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mrow> <mn>20</mn></mrow> </msubsup> <msup> <mi>W</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> </mrow> </mstyle><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbiqaaG9gqaaaaa aaaaWdbmaapedapaqaa8qaceWGxbGbauaaaSWdaeaapeGaaGimaaWd aeaapeGaaGOmaiaaicdaa0Gaey4kIipakiaacIcacaWG0bGaaiykai aadsgacaWG0baaaa@40E8@ </annotation> </semantics> </math> in the context of this problem.

(c) For 0 ≤ t ≤ 20, the average temperature of the water in the tub is <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mn>1</mn> <mrow> <mn>20</mn></mrow> </mfrac> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mrow> <mn>20</mn></mrow> </msubsup> <mi>W</mi> </mrow> </mstyle><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbiqaaG9gqaaaaa aaaaWdbmaalaaabaGaaGymaaqaaiaaikdacaaIWaaaamaapedapaqa a8qacaWGxbaal8aabaWdbiaaicdaa8aabaWdbiaaikdacaaIWaaani abgUIiYdGccaGGOaGaamiDaiaacMcacaWGKbGaamiDaaaa@431D@ </annotation> </semantics> </math>. Use a left Riemann sum with the four subintervals indicated by the data in  the table to approximate <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mn>1</mn> <mrow> <mn>20</mn></mrow> </mfrac> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mrow> <mn>20</mn></mrow> </msubsup> <mi>W</mi> </mrow> </mstyle><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbiqaaG9gqaaaaa aaaaWdbmaalaaabaGaaGymaaqaaiaaikdacaaIWaaaamaapedapaqa a8qacaWGxbaal8aabaWdbiaaicdaa8aabaWdbiaaikdacaaIWaaani abgUIiYdGccaGGOaGaamiDaiaacMcacaWGKbGaamiDaaaa@431D@ </annotation> </semantics> </math>. Does this approximation overestimate or underestimate the average temperature of the water over these 20 minutes? Explain your reasoning.

(d) For 20 ≤ t ≤ 25, the function W that models the water temperature has first derivative given by  <math> <semantics> <mrow> <msup> <mi>W</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.4</mn><msqrt> <mi>t</mi> </msqrt> <mi>cos</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mn>0.06</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow> <mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbiqaaG9gceWGxb GbauaacaGGOaGaamiDaiaacMcaqaaaaaaaaaWdbiabg2da9iaaicda caGGUaGaaGinamaakaaapaqaa8qacaWG0baaleqaaOGaci4yaiaac+ gacaGGZbWaaeWaa8aabaWdbiaaicdacaGGUaGaaGimaiaaiAdacaWG 0baacaGLOaGaayzkaaaaaa@470D@ </annotation> </semantics> </math>. Based on the model, what is the temperature of the water at time t = 25?

topic.text: 2.3: Estimating Derivatives of a Function at a Point

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
